name: Java Variables
description: Variable declaration, initialization, scope, types, and lifecycle in Java.

questions.title: Variable Declaration
questions.description: Which of the following is a valid variable declaration in Java?
questions.explanation: Variable names must start with a letter, underscore, or dollar sign, and cannot be Java keywords. 'number2' is the only valid identifier.

questions.title: Local Variable Scope
questions.description: Where can a local variable be accessed?
questions.explanation: Local variables are accessible within the method where they are declared and in any nested blocks within that method.

questions.title: Instance Variable Default
questions.description: What is the default value of an instance variable of type int?
questions.explanation: Instance variables are automatically initialized to default values. For int, the default value is 0.

questions.title: Static Variable
questions.description: What is true about static variables in Java?
options: Each object has its own copy
Shared among all instances of the class
Cannot be accessed without creating an object
questions.explanation: Static variables belong to the class rather than any instance. All objects of the class share the same static variable.

questions.title: Variable Initialization
questions.description: What happens when you compile this code?
questions.explanation: Local variables must be initialized before use. Since 'x' is not initialized, this causes a compilation error.

questions.title: Final Variable
questions.description: What happens when you try to modify a final variable?
questions.code:
final int x = 10;
x = 20;
questions.explanation: Final variables cannot be reassigned after initialization. Attempting to do so results in a compilation error.

questions.title: Variable Naming Rules
questions.description: Which variable name is NOT valid in Java?
questions.explanation: Variable names cannot start with a digit. They must begin with a letter, underscore (_), or dollar sign ($).

questions.title: Block Scope

questions.explanation: This causes a compilation error because you cannot declare a variable with the same name in a nested block when it already exists in the outer scope.

questions.title: Class Variable Access
questions.description: How can you access a static variable?
options: Both through class name and object
questions.explanation: Static variables can be accessed both through the class name (MyClass.count) and through an object reference, though class name access is preferred.

questions.title: Variable Shadowing
questions.description: What is variable shadowing in Java?
questions.explanation: Variable shadowing occurs when a local variable or parameter has the same name as an instance variable, hiding the instance variable in that scope.

questions.title: Constant Declaration
questions.description: What is the conventional way to declare a constant in Java?
questions.explanation: Constants are conventionally declared as 'static final' with uppercase names. Java doesn't have 'const' or 'readonly' keywords.

questions.title: Variable Lifecycle
questions.description: When is a local variable destroyed?
questions.explanation: Local variables are destroyed when the method execution completes and the method's stack frame is removed.

questions.title: Multiple Variable Declaration
questions.description: Which is a valid way to declare multiple variables?
questions.explanation: Option C is correct. Option A only initializes 'c', leaving 'a' and 'b' uninitialized. Option B is invalid syntax in Java.

questions.title: Parameter Variables
questions.description: What type of variables are method parameters?
questions.explanation: Method parameters are treated as local variables within the method scope. They are automatically initialized with the values passed to the method.

questions.title: Variable Initialization Order
questions.description: In what order are variables initialized in a Java class?
questions.explanation: Static variables are initialized first when the class is loaded, then instance variables are initialized when an object is created.

questions.title: Blank Final Variable
questions.description: What is a blank final variable?
options: A final variable with no value
A final variable initialized in constructor
questions.explanation: A blank final variable is a final variable that is not initialized at declaration but must be initialized in the constructor.

questions.title: Variable Memory Location
questions.description: Where are local variables stored in memory?
questions.explanation: Local variables are stored in the stack memory. Each method call creates a new stack frame containing local variables and parameters.

questions.title: Instance Variable Access
questions.description: How do you access an instance variable when it's shadowed by a local variable?
questions.explanation: Use 'this.x' to access the instance variable when it's shadowed by a local variable with the same name.

questions.title: Variable Type Inference
questions.description: What does the 'var' keyword do in Java 10+?
questions.code: var number = 42;
options: Infers the variable type from initializer
questions.explanation: The 'var' keyword enables local variable type inference. The compiler determines the type from the initializer expression.

questions.title: Static Variable Initialization
questions.description: When are static variables initialized?
options: When the class is first loaded
questions.explanation: Static variables are initialized when the class is first loaded by the JVM, before any objects are created.

questions.title: Variable Modifier Combinations
questions.description: Which combination of modifiers is valid for a variable?
questions.explanation: All combinations are valid. Variables can have multiple modifiers like 'static final' for constants, 'private static' for class-level private variables, etc.

questions.title: Loop Variable Scope
questions.description: What is the scope of the loop variable 'i'?
questions.explanation: The loop variable 'i' is only accessible within the for loop block. It goes out of scope when the loop ends.

questions.title: Variable Default Values
questions.description: Which primitive type has 'false' as its default value?
questions.explanation: The boolean primitive type has 'false' as its default value for instance and static variables.

questions.title: Reference Variable Default
questions.description: What is the default value of a reference variable?
questions.explanation: All reference variables (objects) have 'null' as their default value when declared as instance or static variables.

questions.title: Variable Reassignment
questions.description: What happens in this code?
questions.explanation: Variables can be reassigned unless they are final. The variable 'x' is reassigned to 20, so it prints 20.

questions.title: Anonymous Block Variables
questions.description: What is the scope of variables declared in an anonymous block?
questions.explanation: Variables declared in anonymous blocks (instance initializer blocks) are only accessible within that block.

questions.title: Variable Hiding
questions.description: What concept is demonstrated in this code?
questions.explanation: This demonstrates variable hiding. The child class variable 'x' hides the parent class variable 'x'. Both variables exist but the child's version is accessed by default.

questions.title: Effective Final Variables
questions.description: What makes a variable 'effectively final' in Java?
questions.explanation: A variable is effectively final if it's not declared final but is never reassigned after initialization. Such variables can be used in lambda expressions and inner classes.

questions.title: Variable Memory Management
questions.description: When is memory for a local variable deallocated?
questions.explanation: The local variable reference is removed when the method ends, but the actual object memory is deallocated when the garbage collector runs and determines the object is no longer reachable.

questions.title: Variable Best Practices
questions.description: Which is considered a best practice for variable naming in Java?
questions.explanation: Java convention uses camelCase for variable names (e.g., firstName, totalAmount). ALL_CAPS is reserved for constants, and single letters should be avoided except for short loop counters.
